cards.name: Limitless Potential
cards.originalText:
As Limitless Potential enters the battlefield, choose a land type.
Lands you control and land cards you own that aren't on the battlefield are the chosen type in addition to their other types.

rulings.text: Can affect basic or non-basic types, but it must be for a specific type. The chosen type must be an existing land type. See the glossary of the comprehensive rulebook for more details on existing land types.
If a basic land type is chosen, all lands you control and land cards you own that aren't on the battlefield also gain the corresponding mana ability, e.g. “{T}: Add {R}.” if Mountain is chosen.
Choosing a nonbasic land type doesn't grant anything any additional abilities. For example, choosing Tower doesn't grant lands the ability printed on Urza's Tower.

Since this affects land cards that aren't on the battlefield, it works with landcycling abilities. For example, choosing Island and then activating an islandcycling ability allows you to search for any land card in your library.
However, choosing a basic land type does not make all land cards basic. For example, choosing Island and then activating Terramorphic Expanse's ability doesn't allow you to search for a Lost Cavern.

cards.name: Cast Aside Death
cards.originalText:
Voyage ({W}{U}{B}{R}{G}: You discover paradise for the rest of the game.)
You can't lose the game.
Whenever you lose life, sacrifice that many permanents. Then if you've discovered paradise, draw that many cards.

rulings.text: Since the mana symbols are reminder text, not rules text, voyage does not contribute to a card's color identity. This card's color identity is black.
While you can't lose the game, your opponents can still win the game if an effect says so.
While you control Cast Aside Death, your life total still changes. Cast Aside Death's effects don't replace the life loss.

If you run out of other permanents, you'll have to sacrifice Cast Aside Death itself. You can then lose the game again, for example if the same trigger made you draw cards from an empty library, or if your life total is negative.
If you're dealt more damage than you have permanents to sacrifice, you'll just sacrifice everything you can.

cards.name: World Elemental
cards.originalText:
World Elemental gets +1/+1 for each differently named permanent you control.
At the beginning of your end step, gain control of target permanent that doesn't share a name with a permanent you control.

rulings.text: Unless specified otherwise, the name of a token is the same as its subtypes. For example, if you're instructed to create a 1/1 white Human Soldier creature token, that token's name is “Human Soldier”.
Sealed permanents don't have names, so they aren't counted for the first ability.

A permanent with no name has a different name from every other permanent, even another permanent with no name. For example, if all you control is a World Elemental and two Relics (nameless artifacts from Ruins of Doharum), World Elemental is a 3/3. Yes, seriously. Rule 201.2c.

This counts the number of permanents with different names, not the number of different names among permanents you control. Therefore, it won't get ridiculously large if you have a Spy Kit equipped to a creature.

cards.name: Echoshells
cards.originalText:
{T}: Add one mana of any type that a land you control could produce.
{3}, {T}: Search your library for a land card that doesn't share a name with a land you control, put it onto the battlefield, then shuffle your library.

rulings.text: Any replacement effects are considered by Echoshells when determining the types of mana a land can produce.
Any change to a land's type or splicing of text into a land can affect the types of mana a land can produce.
The types of mana are white, blue, black, red, green, and colorless.

Echoshells checks the effects of all mana-producing abilities of lands you control, but it doesn't check their costs. For example, Vivid Crag says “{T}, Remove a charge counter from Vivid Crag: Add one mana of any color.” If you control Vivid Crag and Echoshells, you can tap Echoshells for any color of mana. It doesn't matter whether Vivid Crag has a charge counter on it, and it doesn't matter whether it's untapped.
Echoshells doesn't care about any restrictions or riders your lands put on the mana they produce, such as Pillar of the Paruns and Hall of the Bandit Lord do. It just cares about types of mana.
